summary: This is an email exchange between FBI personnel regarding the management and tracking of evidence items (with NY Cart numbers) related to an investigation, likely the Epstein case, as indicated by the EFTA document number and protective order reference. The email discusses checking on specific evidence items, determining duplicates, and obtaining cart numbers.

persons.name: M. . (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: FBI NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Sender of the email, identified as the NY CART Coordinator and Senior Forensic Examiner, responding to a request about evidence items.

persons.name: (NY) (P131)
persons.context: Recipient and original requester, a Special Agent in the FBI New York Field Office's Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit, asking for assistance with evidence tracking.

connections.description: FBI colleagues coordinating on evidence management tasks; one is a forensic examiner/coordinator, the other is a special agent requesting assistance.

events.title: Evidence tracking request
events.description: An FBI Special Agent emails the NY CART Coordinator to request checking on multiple evidence items (with identifiers like 18 53, 16 57, etc.), asking for their NY Cart numbers and to identify duplicates.

keyFacts: The document is an internal FBI email from October 2020 concerning evidence management in an investigation, likely related to Epstein given the EFTA document number.
Evidence items are referenced with identifiers like '18 53', '16 57', '16 29', '18 30', '1B 32', etc., and are associated with NY Cart numbers (e.g., 024329).
The email indicates ongoing evidence processing and tracking, with questions about duplicates and cart number associations.
The communication is between a Special Agent in the Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit and a Senior Forensic Examiner/CART Coordinator.
The document is subject to a protective order (paragraphs 7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17), indicating sensitive or restricted information.
